<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>

<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_linux_irq_shutdown:
```c
void metal_linux_irq_shutdown(void)
{
	int ret;

	metal_log(METAL_LOG_DEBUG, "%s\n", __func__);
	irq_handling_stop = true;
	metal_linux_irq_notify();
	ret = pthread_join(irq_pthread, NULL);
	if (ret) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "Failed to join IRQ thread: %d.\n",
			  ret);
	}
	close(irq_notify_fd);
	metal_mutex_deinit(&irq_lock);
}
```
</target_code>

static int metal_linux_irq_notify(void)
{
	uint64_t val = 1;
	int ret;

	ret = write(irq_notify_fd, &val, sizeof(val));
	if (ret < 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "%s failed\n", __func__);
	}
	return ret;
}
...
static pthread_t irq_pthread
</additional code>

explanation:
I inspected all controlling expressions in the provided code. The only conditional statements are:
- if (ret) in metal_linux_irq_shutdown — ret is assigned from pthread_join(irq_pthread, NULL) immediately beforehand, so the controlling expression depends on the runtime return value of pthread_join and is not invariant.
- if (ret < 0) in metal_linux_irq_notify — ret is assigned from write(irq_notify_fd, &val, sizeof(val)), so the controlling expression depends on the runtime return value of write and is not invariant.
There are no loops (while, for, do-while) or switch statements with constant/invariant controlling expressions in the provided snippets. The assignment irq_handling_stop = true is not a controlling expression. Therefore there are no code fragments in the supplied code that appear to violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 and nothing needs to be flagged for further investigation.
